awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Auto-flocculation technology for wastewater treatment
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of wastewater treatment technology.  Currently, wastewater treatment plants (WWTPs) consume greater than a third of the energy used by the municipality, with aeration operation utilizing up to 80% of this energy. WWTPs also are one of the largest greenhouse gas emitters with their direct emissions estimated at 1.6% of global inventory.  The proposed technology uses auto-flocculation to enhance primary clarification of wastewater treatment, a basic unit operation in all wastewater treatment applications.  Enhancing primary clarification by using the proposed auto-flocculation technology may reduce organic and nutrient loading to secondary treatment processes. Therefore, the technology has the potential to reduce treatment infrastructure outlay, energy cost for aeration in activated sludge, and carbon footprint of wastewater treatment.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of auto-flocculation technology for enhanced primary clarification in wastewater treatment. Currently, in primary clarification, particles are removed by gravity-based sedimentation from the bulk water. The efficacy of this primary treatment process is typically about 50%. Following primary clarification, wastewater is subjected to secondary treatment, such as activated sludge, requiring intense infrastructure requirements, high energy use, and greenhouse gas emissions.  In addition, enhanced primary treatment of wastewater often requires conditioning chemicals, which is unsustainable and often compromises downstream bioprocesses, and/or significant retrofitting of conventional clarifiers.  However, wastewater possesses significant self-aggregating potential, which is currently unrealized in conventional wastewater treatment. The proposed auto-flocculation process does not require chemicals nor clarifiers' retrofit but employs agitation of wastewater prior to clarification, which enables 80-90% of primary treatment efficacy.  Greater capture of carbon rich solids by the proposed auto-flocculation technology at the primary treatment stage is expected to render wastewater treatment plants with a path toward carbon neutral industry.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Gravity separation constitutes a basic unit operation in all wastewater treatment applications where particles settle out of the bulk water. The efficacy of this primary treatment process is typically about 50%. The remaining unsettled particles in water are then treated by secondary processes, accounting for intense infrastructure requirement, high energy use, and greenhouse gas emissions. Enhanced primary treatment of wastewater most often requires conditioning chemicals, which is unsustainable and often compromises downstream bioprocesses. 

Team NaturaFloc at the University of Massachusetts has developed technology that centers on the currently unrealized auto-flocculation capacity of wastewater, which can enhance primary treatment. Enhanced removal of carbon-rich particles by this natural flocculation and sedimentation can thus reduce energy cost and carbon footprint of wastewater treatment. Furthermore, it can allow processing and treating larger quantities of wastewater, which has become more important in the changing climate. Amid the team's continued effort on developing technology, they wanted to investigate and determine its market-product fit, and this project has been a great opportunity for them to achieve that goal.

Team NaturaFloc participating in the NSF I-Corps cohort was composed of a harmonious blend of four members, the postdoctoral entrepreneurial lead; the two co-technical leads by one postdoctoral researcher and one faculty member; and the industry mentor who brought unparalleled industry insights and expertise to the team, each contributing their unique experience and expertise to the pursuit of innovative wastewater treatment solutions. Along with completion of the cohort training over a seven-week period, the team conducted 111 interviews with various stakeholders in the wastewater field representing 15 countries and 32 states in the U.S.

From their customer discovery process, the team could identify key pain points in the wastewater field, and the top 5 points were: 1) Regulatory compliance; 2) Aging infrastructure and required maintenance; 3) Biosolids disposal and nutrient removal; 4) Risk adverse and resistance to change; and 5) Capacity enhancement with existing footprint.

Furthermore, key lessons that the team learned include: 1) Change in the wastewater treatment field is driven by regulatory requirements, aging infrastructure, and the imperative to enhance capacity; 2) Waste lagoon systems prefer simplicity and cost-effectiveness over adopting new technology that adds complexity or operational costs; and 3) The industrial wastewater sector is probably more accessible than the municipal sector, but thorough laboratory and market research is crucial before deciding. With these, the team identified that NaturaFloc technology’s main customer is municipal wastewater treatment plants.

The team was able to establish the value proposition of NaturaFloc technology as: 1) Increases the treatment capacity by 20%; 2) Cuts the energy costs by 20%; 3) Reduces the sludge handling costs by 20%; 4) Increases biogas production in biosolids digestion; and 5) Decreases CO2 emissions by 20%. Overall, the team anticipates that municipalities will adopt NaturaFloc to achieve a 20% increase in treatment capacity and a 20% reduction in energy and biosolids handling costs.

One critical result that the team learned is that strong evidence from pilot testing is almost mandatory in new technology development and this is also the primary hurdle for many new wastewater technology developers due to investment required for such pilot testing. In the team's customer discovery process, 78% of the 111 interviewees indicated the need for pilot testing to consider product uptake. The team found that piloting could range from $250,000 to $2,000,000 limiting the number of utilities or start-ups capable of undertaking the commercialization pathway successfully.

This project has provided the team with opportunities to meet a large number of industry stakeholders. The customer discovery further aided in establishing partnerships to facilitate product design and demonstration of auto-flocculation of wastewater. To facilitate successful commercialization of technology, the team continues to conduct technology proofing and seeks to secure funding to conduct pilot testing while continuing to establish strong partnerships with industry sectors to develop a viable product and plans for market via licensing.

Overall, through this NSF I-Corps program, the team has not only refined technology but also fostered a culture of innovation within the wastewater treatment industry. By engaging with plant operators, industry experts, and potential users, the team was not only addressing immediate challenges in wastewater treatment but also promoting a paradigm shift towards sustainable and efficient practices. The insights gained from customer discovery have not only enhanced the development of NaturaFloc but have the potential to influence industry-wide approaches to wastewater treatment. As the team fine-tunes the product-market fit, they are simultaneously working towards advancing environmental stewardship, energy conservation, and cost-effectiveness in the wastewater treatment sector. These broader impacts extend beyond the commercial viability of NaturaFloc; it signifies a transformative journey towards more sustainable and resilient wastewater treatment practices that align with the evolving needs of society and the environment.
